sect1.title: Support
sect1.para:
The Support panel is used when working with Metavize Support or one of their authorized representatives.
Administrators should not change any properties of the Support panel unless instructed to by a member of Metavize support or one of their authorized representatives.

sect2.title: Access Restrictions
sect2.para: The Access Restrictions tab, as seen in , can enable Metavize Support or one of their authorized representatives to greater assist in troubleshooting.

There are two ways in which Metavize support can assist in troubleshooting. The first is to access the ⪚ remotely via a secure protocol (SSH). This is enabled by selecting Allow, and disabled by selecting Disallow.
By default, SSH access is disabled.

Administrators can also choose to have their ⪚ send internal log messages to Metavize Support in the event of unexpected conditions. These logs are internal to the product, and not only assist in troubleshooting but help Metavize produce a better product. To enable such emails to be sent to Metavize support, check the box labeled Report.

sect2.title: Manual Protocol Overrides
sect2.para:
The Manual Protocol Overrides tab contains advanced properties for Web, Email and FTP traffic. These will be discussed in , , and respectively.
Administrators should not change any Protocol Settings unless instructed to by a member of Metavize support or one of their authorized representatives.

sect3.title: HTTP Settings
sect3.para:
The HTTP Settings tab of the Manual Protocol Override tab is seen in .
Administrators should not change the HTTP Settings tab unless instructed to by a member of Metavize support or one of their authorized representatives.

The HTTP Settings tab of the Manual Protocol Override tab is divided into four sections. The first, Web Override disables processing of all HTTP traffic for all Software Appliances. This should normally be set to Enable Processing unless under special circumstances (for example, you are a software company debugging your own web-enabled products).
Long URIs (see URIs) and Long Headers control the ⪚ behavior with abnormal web traffic. The default settings accommodate most standard web traffic.

Non-HTTP Blocking is used to control the ⪚ behavior for non-http traffic over port 80. The default behavior is to allow such traffic. Selecting the Stop option may prevent applications such as peer-to-peer file sharing or networked games from operating correctly. Note that normal web traffic (from a browser to a web server) is not effected by this setting.

sect3.title: Mail Settings
sect3.para:
The Mail Settings tab of the Manual Protocol OVerride Tab can be seen in .
Administrators should not change the Mail Settings tab unless instructed to by a member of Metavize support or one of their authorized representatives.
The Mail Settings tab is divided into two sections, Email Overrides and Email Timeouts. Each section can control settings for the three supported email protocols, SMTP, POP, and IMAP.
Email Overrides lets Administrators turn off scanning for a given email protocol. This applies to all Software Appliances. For example, disabling SMTP would affect SPAM, Virus and Phish scanning.

The Email Timeouts section instructs the ⪚ as to the maximum time it has for scanning. If a given email takes more than this time to process, scanning is aborted and the mail passed to the client. Note that setting this value too small risks passing contaminated content, and setting it too large risks timeouts in client programs (with user complaints to follow).
Default values are 30 seconds. This is a large value relative to expected mail traffic, and should satisfy most normal installations.

sect3.title: File Transfer
sect3.para: The File Transfer (FTP) tab is seen in .

From this tab, Administrators can turn on/off scanning of FTP traffic by selecting either Enable Processing or Disable Processing, respectively. If disabled, no software appliances within the ⪚ will scan FTP traffic.

sect2.title: Network Interfaces
sect2.para: The Network Interfaces Tab, as seen in , allows administrators to configure the behavior of the ethernet ports on the ⪚ machine.
When interfacing with old hardware, it may be nessecary to downgrade a given port from its default Auto-Negotiate setting to a more limiting setting.

Networking hardware which requires transfer rate limitation (100/10 Mbps) or which cannot auto-negotiate has not been readily available for several years. It is unlikely that Administrators will have to modify these settings.
